data.title: Added Tween.animateProperties()
data.body: ...to support tweening multiple properties with a single call.  Also, this allows properties hashed in the Object to be updated later using the same Object.

data.title: Support of the new ATF format
data.body:
Adobe announced new version of ATF format:
"Starting Flash player 11.8 and AIR 3.8 beta, we have introduced 4096x4096 texture support in runtimes. Now, we're glad to announce the beta version of new ATF tools to generate the 4096x4096 ATF textures. The ATF format has now changed with the new tools and you will have to use swf-version 21 in your applications, otherwise you will encounter an “Internal Decoding Error”."

So, there are some parsing issues in starling.textures.AtfData now.

Beta version of the tool is here - http://labsdownload.adobe.com/pub/labs/flashruntimes/air/atf_tools.zip

data.title: ATF textures not working in chrome - default release player
data.body:
Chrome flash player driver in Chrome uses render mode "OpenGL" instead of "DirectX9" 
Could that be a reason why ATF textures do not work? If I use a debug player in chrome it shows "DirectX9" and the project works as expected. All other browsers are fine except Chrome.

Chrome 28.0.1500.37 beta-m
Flash Player version: WIN 11,7,700,203

Using multiple TextureAtlases to load embedded ATFs.
For packaging textures, PNGs were generated using Texture Packer.
2048x2048 (RGBA8888)

ATFs generated using the following command:

``` javascript
png2atf.exe -4 -i texture_atlas.png -o texture_atlas.atf
```

if you open the same link in Chrome and FF/IE different driver info will be displayed.
http://helpx.adobe.com/x-productkb/multi/stage3d-unsupported-chipsets-drivers-flash.html

On the other hand ATF textures in Alternativa3D engine work fine in Chrome. It's just Starling that has a problem.

Any ideas?

data.title: Handling of duplicate assets in the AssetManager
data.body:
Hi there,

Is it possible to get support for the handling of duplicate assets? Like to have the choice to "force add" an asset when there is already an asset with the same name?

Or that the `mTextures` can be read out somehow so I can check if a texture is already enqueued.

Kind regards,
Peter Goes

p.s. I can write the code for reading out the `mTextures` if you want to

data.title: DisplayObjectContainer - reset mChildren
Possible to offer an ordered array of Context3DProfile choices?
data.body:
Minor feature request, but related to discovering that with the latest 3.8 SDK beta one can only use RectangleTexture with Context3DProfile.BASELINE and Context3DProfile.BASELINE_EXTENDED, and as another example, 4096 textures are only available with Context3DProfile.BASELINE_EXTENDED.

One might want to design a cross-platform app (desktop + iOS + Android) and might want to both conditionally support 4096 textures (if the device supports it), or separately also use RectangleTexture (if the device supports it).

So instead of designing my Starling app to pick one universal profile choice, I'd like to be able to tell Starling, try using Context3DProfile.BASELINE_EXTENDED, if it fails to create a Context3D, fallback to Context3DProfile.BASELINE, and finally if it doesn't support either of those fallback to Context3DProfile.BASELINE_CONSTRAINED.

Then knowing which profile at runtime was used I can easily deal with conditionally creating RectangleTextures or 4096 textures because I now know the active profile at runtime.

If you aren't keen at allowing an ordered array of optional profile choices for the Starling constructor, maybe you could at least show or provide a minimal implementation of a profile supported util function like:

public function supportsProfile(profile:String):Boolean that at least developers could optionally call at startup to externally run fallback code if their app desired it and then pass a pofile to the Starling constructor in the existing way.

Thanks

data.title: New Event for starling.display.Button when button is held down first
data.body:
I came across the need to loop a sound while a button is held down, and stop the loop when it's released aka Event.TRIGGERED

I achieved it by fireing an event when the button is first pressed, before it was triggered.

feel free to rename the event

data.title: AssetManager crashes when call canceled
data.body:
I have a Sprite (loader animation) which uses the new AssetManager. Sometimes the loader is removed before the AssetManager is ready with loading of the actual assets. Then the AssetManager throws an NPE on line 362:

``` as3
loadRawAsset(assetInfo.name, assetInfo.asset, xmls, progress, resume);
```

This is because the assetInfo is null which is caused by the delayed call on processNext. Apparently the mRawAssets is removed in the meantime. I've just added below code above the mRawAssets.pop() as a quick fix:

``` as3
if(mRawAssets.length == 0)
return;
```

Is this a valid issue or am I doning something wrong with the AssetManager?

Regards!

data.title: EventDispatcher: optimized access of listener[i] in removeEventListener()
data.body: Saved listener[i] into a variable so that you don't need to access it twice while looping.

data.title: DisplayObjectContainer dispose does dispose children but do not wipe the mChildren
data.body:
Hi,

In the dispose method of DisplayObjectContainer, dont you think you should nullify the mChildren array (or at least empty it) to avoid potential circular reference issue (displayObjectContainer is the mParent of it's children) ?

Because at the moment we do removeChildren(0, -1, true); then dispose. Avoiding the removeChildren call would skip a lot of events broadcast :)

Thanks,

Sebastien

data.title: Drawing to BitmapData with RenderSupport skips objects with clipRect defined
data.body:
Observed behavior:
- When drawing DisplayObjects to a BitmapData using RenderSupport, any DisplayObjects in the hierarchy with clipRect defined are not rendered at all.

Desired behavior:
- Clip rectangles are properly applied when render to bitmapdata

Testcase:  http://onetacoshort.com/temp/render_clip.zip

data.title: Access to the atlases in AssetManager
data.body: It would be good to add to starling.utils.AssetManager function that returns a list of atlases, or their names in order to have access to the atlases. Now variable mAtlases is private and there is no way to get it.

data.title: removeFromParent > improve
RenderSupport internal mQuadBatches loitering? Offer an optional trim()?
data.body:
This may be a minor issue/feature request for most apps, but I wanted to at least mention it in case it could/would be part of any more significant refactoring for Starling 1.4+ changes.

What I notice in my app, where I sometimes have to load a lot of active simultaneous content, or sometimes switch to not very much active content, (especially with using Feathers controls where clipping rects and lists are active, and then not shown) is that my active draw counts (== use of active mQuadBatches length in RenderSupport) can jump around from 1-3 and then sometimes temporarily up to around 50-60 active mQuadBatches in RenderSupport, but then fall back down to a steady use of 1-5 draw counts.

I notice internally in RenderSupport it uses an mQuadBatches vector and pushes as needed, new QuadBatch instances as more are needed.

Now I understand the need to not reset the length of mQuadBatches.length = 1 inside nextFrame() as this would cause a crazy new amount of QuadBatch instances to be made and slow things down greatly, but then my understanding is that the length of mQuadBatches will always stay as large as the most active draw count an app will ever get to, and then never dispose of any of the QuadBatch instances in this vector (even if the app rarely, or never, returns to that active peak draw count).

Profiling the app seems to show these extra QuadBatches (and corresponding vertex and index buffers) taking up memory.

Would it be possible to offer some sort of trim() on Starling (and thus RenderSupport) that could do a trimming of the current mQuadBatches length (as well as calling dispose() on the extra QuadBatches removed)?

Of course a developer wouldn't want to call this trim() very often, but if we knew we just closed a very active screen that was an abnormal amount of draw counts, could we not then clean up/release extra QuadBatch memory use?

Thanks
Jeff

data.title: render mode software
data.body:
Hi guys,

I'm trying to use render mode software for iOS, but it does not work.
It works on desktop emulator, but not on device. 
As I understand the event starling.events.Event.ROOT_CREATED does not dispatching.
Is it possible to use this mode for mobile?

data.title: removeChildren() needs to be recursive to prevent memory leaks
data.body:
I've been doing a bunch of experiments with cleaning up my display objects after they're no longer required and have noticed that objects that contain nested display lists (ie. a Sprite containing another Sprite which contains yet more Sprites) are not releasing memory properly.

My fix is to manually call removeChildren(0, -1, true) in each of child display objects.

For mine, having DisplayObjectContainer.removeChildren() should be doing this recursively automatically.

data.title: Starling reporting different contentScaleFactors when launching on desktop and on device/simulator
data.body:
After recent pull from repo Starling.current.contentScaleFactor reports different content scale factors when launching app on desktop and on iOS device. 

Please see here http://forum.starling-framework.org/topic/difference-in-font-quality-between-debug-and-on-device

data.title: Update AssetManager.as
data.body:
get the correct extension with url like this:
"abc/xyz.extension?get_param=something"

data.title: Browser zoom scaling problem after reload
data.body:
When scaling the page up (100% and above) without listening to any resize events, the swf content holds the correct scale and isn't scaled up or down. However if the browser zoom level is set to below 100%, and then the project is loaded (or refreshed), the content becomes scaled up. Problem with mClippedViewPort occurs because mNativeStage.stageWidth and mNativeStage.stageHeight are different from the original viewport dimensions. Te touch listeners are in the right spots though. Replacing mClippedViewPort with current mViewPort size fixes the problem, but this probably isn't the right solution to this issue.

Stalring.as - Line 435:
mClippedViewPort = mViewPort.intersection(
   new Rectangle(0, 0, mNativeStage.stageWidth, mNativeStage.stageHeight)); // incorrect scale

//mClippedViewPort = mViewPort; // correct scale

data.title: movieclip reverse playback and "bounce" loop
data.body:
added functionality to `MovieClip` to allow reverse playback and "bounce" loop -- play forward and backward as a loop.

both are fully compatible with `MovieClip`'s existing features. setting `bounceLoop = true` will set `loop = false` and setting `loop = true` will set `bounceLoop = false`, since the two cannot both be true at once.  `reverse` works whether or not `loop` or `bounceLoop` are set.

there are two commits in this pull request because i implemented these changes against an out-of-date version of `MovieClip` and had to go back and reimplement them against the latest version.  better to look at the MovieClip.as diff than to look through the individual commits.

i haven't tested with your unit tests as i don't have that test suite set up, but i manually tested all the permutations of `loop`, `bounceLoop`, `reverse`, and an `Event.COMPLETE` handler that i could come up with.

data.title: added reverse playback and "bounce" looping
data.body:
`reverse` accessor allows reverse `MovieClip` playback.
`bounceLoop` accessor allows `MovieClip` playback that changes direction when it hits the start or end of the `MovieClip`.

data.title: added progress accessor to Tween
data.body:
find a Tween's progress, as determined by its transition function, from
0 to 1. previously, this was calculated only within animate() (and was
inefficiently calculated separately for each tweened property).

useful for updating things in a Tween's onUpdate() callback in sync with the Tween's progress, when it's not possible for the Tween to do the update itself.  (e.g. update a Sprite's filter values)

data.title: Added property 'paused' to Juggler
added progress accessor to Tween
data.body:
find a Tween's progress, as determined by its transition function, from
0 to 1.  previously, this was calculated only within animate() (and was
inefficiently calculated separately for each tweened property).

(moved this feature to a different branch, to disambiguate from my other open (TextField) pull request...)

data.title: DisplayObject seemingly randomly flips while setting transformationMatrix
data.body:
Under certain circumstances (that only the Gods of Matrix Math understand) when setting transformationMatrix, the display object will flip (invert scale) in both in the X and Y directions.  This is not desirable when the user has stored off stateful variables and is trying to make comparisons over time, as is often the case with drag-and-rotate touch handlers.

I have such a drag-and-rotate handler, and the object being rotated erratically flips without my fix. With the fix, it behaves perfectly.

The alternative (which I suspect many people have implemented) is to detect this flip condition after setting the transformation matrix, but that's cumbersome at every assignment.
